user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_SHA512_256_update:
```c
void
MHD_SHA512_256_update (struct Sha512_256Ctx *ctx,
                       const uint8_t *data,
                       size_t length)
{
  unsigned int bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in the context buffer */
  uint64_t count_hi; /**< The high part to be moved to another variable */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned int) (ctx->count & (SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 7
  if (length > ctx->count)
    ctx->count_bits_hi += 1U << 3; /* Value wrap */
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 7 */
  count_hi = ctx->count >> 61;
  if (0 != count_hi)
  {
    ctx->count_bits_hi += count_hi;
    ctx->count &= UINT64_C (0x1FFFFFFFFFFFFFFF);
  }

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned int bytes_left = SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process the full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      sha512_256_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    sha512_256_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Most of the function already uses const qualification where appropriate (the input parameter is declared as const uint8_t *data) or necessarily works with mutable state (ctx is modified, ctx->H and count fields are updated), so those locations do not need investigation for Rule 8.13. Pointer arithmetic and modification of the local pointer variable 'data' is intentional for buffer traversal and does not imply the pointed-to type lacks const where it should. The flagged fragments are the only places in this function that (a) perform casts that may remove const qualification from a buffer pointer and (b) call the transform function with buffer/data pointers where the target function prototype’s const-qualification should be checked. All other lines either operate on mutable context state or already use const-qualified pointee types and therefore do not need further inspection for Rule 8.13.
